question.title: Employees Earning More Than Their Managers
question.content:
Employees Earning More Than Their Managers
 The Employee table holds all employees including their managers. Every employee has an Id, and there is also a column for the manager Id.

+----+-------+--------+-----------+
| Id | Name  | Salary | ManagerId |
+----+-------+--------+-----------+
| 1  | Joe   | 70000  | 3         |
| 2  | Henry | 80000  | 4         |
| 3  | Sam   | 60000  | NULL      |
| 4  | Max   | 90000  | NULL      |
+----+-------+--------+-----------+
Given the Employee table, write a SQL query that finds out employees who earn more than their managers. For the above table, Joe is the only employee who earns more than his manager.

+----------+
| Employee |
+----------+
| Joe      |
+----------+

rephrased.body: Given an `Employee` table with columns `Id`, `Name`, `Salary`, and `ManagerId`, find all employees who earn a higher salary than their direct manager.  The `ManagerId` column references the `Id` of the employee's manager.

testcases.explanation: Joe (Id 1, Salary 70000) reports to Sam (Id 3, Salary 60000). Joe's salary is greater than Sam's. Henry (Id 2, Salary 80000) reports to Max (Id 4, Salary 90000). Henry's salary is not greater than Max's. Thus, only Joe satisfies the condition.

Joe (Id 1, Salary 70000) reports to Sam (Id 3, Salary 90000). Joe's salary is not greater than Sam's. Henry (Id 2, Salary 60000) reports to Max (Id 4, Salary 70000). Henry's salary is not greater than Max's. Thus, only Joe and Henry satisfy the condition.
